_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Milk Specialties Global has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM 
related activities. 

1.1 Milk Specialties Global, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Milk Specialties Global has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                     | Process Chemical                    | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration Process      Anhydrous Ammonia                     11,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.
Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulati

on to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

1.2 Process Descriptions

Facility Overview

Milk Specialties operates a production facility for dairy products in Visalia, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
(15) Silos
(2) Ice Builders
(4) Falling Film Chillers
(3) Plate and Frame Heat Exchangers 
(1) Upper Vat Room Air Handling Unit

Facility Location
Milk Specialties is located at 715 N. Divisadero Street Visalia, CA 93291. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.33636018, -119.31210. The facility is located approximately ½ mile north of state highway 198 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by businesses and residences.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in a special flood hazard area. The elevation of the machinery room was designed with the flood hazards in mind.

Milk Specialties is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Milk Specialties had a 1-2% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

Description of Covered Processes
Ammonia

The heat exchangers are equipped with surge drums as required for flooded operation. Most control valve groups are located at a working level, on a working platform, or on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the machinery room, the outside machi

nery area, on the roof above the machinery room, and throughout the facility. A partial list of system components includes:

Machinery Room
(7) Reciprocating compressors
(7) Oil separators
(1) Ice Builder with an integral Surge Drum
(1) Falling Film Chiller with an integral Surge Drum
(2) Oil Pots

Outside Machinery Area
(1) High Pressure Receiver
(2) Suction Accumulators
(2) Transfer Vessels
(1) Ice Builder with an integral Surge Drum
(3) Falling Film Chillers each with an integral Surge Drum
(4) Oil Pots
(1) Auto-Purger

Machinery Room Roof
(2) Evaporative condensers
(3) Ventilation fans

Inside Silo Area
(6) Surge Drums
(6) Silos
(6) Oil Pots

Upper Vat Room Roof
(1) Air Handling Unit
(1) Surge Drum

Chiller Room Roof
(2) Surge Drums

Chiller Room
(2) Plate and Frame Heat Exchangers
(1) Oil Pot (located outside room)

Receiving Silo Area
(3) Surge Drums
(3) Silos
(3) Oil Pots

UF Production Area
(6) Silos
(1) Surge Drum

The ammonia refrigeration system at Milk Specialties consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Milk Specialties is treated as a single process.

RAGAGEP Statement

Ammonia Refrigeration

The process equipment was inspected during the PHA for the purpose of verifying that the process was designed, fabricated, and is being operated in accordance with applicable industry standards. It is unclear which  codes and standards were followed in the original design and construction of the refrigeration system. The pressure vessels are equipped with nameplates which span the years 1994-2002. Due to the fact that the system is not equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank, it is the judgment of the PHA team that the system most closely aligns with the 1991 Uniform Mechanical/Fire Codes.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in a

nnual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Milk Specialties Global has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia
The ammonia refrigeration process at the Milk Specialties Global facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates year-round. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 11,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History
Milk Specialties Global has had no accidental releases within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan
Milk Specialties Global's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title

29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Milk Specialties Global has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Milk Specialties Global continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Milk Specialties Global's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Milk Specialties Global's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Milk Specialties Global has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with acce

ss to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Milk Specialties Global has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Milk Specialties Global now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Milk Specialties Global employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Milk Specialties Global will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
